if Statement

The if statement is a syntax that allows you to decide whether or not to execute a part of a script based on a conditional judgment, such as "if XX, then do YY."
The syntax is as follows:

if(expression)
    statement or block
else
    statement or block
The first "statement or block" is executed when the result of evaluating the expression is true, and the second "statement or block" is executed when the result of the evaluation is false. The else part and onwards can be omitted if it is not needed.

Example:
    if(a==b)
        inform("a and b are the same");

    if(a<b)
    {
        var t;
        t=a; a=b; b=t; // swap a and b 
    }

    if(a==b)
        inform("a and b are the same");
    else
        inform("a and b are different");

Correspondence between if and else

else follows the rule that it "corresponds to the preceding if that has not yet been paired with an else."

For example,

    if(expr) // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
        else // ●
            statement;
    else // ★
        statement;
In this case, the ★ else corresponds to the ★ if, and the ● else corresponds to the ● if.
In free-style languages like TJS2, even if you make a mistake in indentation and write it as follows:

    if(expr) // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
    else // ●
        statement;
the correspondence remains as described above, so you need to be careful.
If you want to clearly separate the correspondences, use a method such as enclosing them in blocks like this:

    if(expr) { // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
    }
    else // ★
        statement;
